message: I hope someone on the panel is representing vim
Todd forgot to say that Komodo now supports Django nicely
@ericasberry That gives me great-sadness.
Hmmm, PyCon discount for PyCharm?  ;)
vim++
ok, who won? (visual studio on linux !!??)
I'm in the pypes talk, so I'm counting on you guys to let me know who wins, LOL
I was wondering about vim, but seemed to really say straight IDE and IDE products
I have to say PyCharm is lookin' pretty sweet
I believe Wing is the only IDE here written in Python.
@ericasberry I need to see if I can finagle myself a license. The early access builds were really nice.
But emacs is represented - LOL
PyCharm is really nice.  They had a 50% off when in beta.  They also have a free trial.
I know they added Django templates, but I don't think any other languages
not at this session, but +1 for PyCharm. Secondary +1 to emacs...
First was Visual Studio.
Obviously not a problem for Visual Studio... and emacs I don't need to mention.
PyCharm django template code completion is pretty sweet
which was the first IDE that presented in this panel?
Wing USED to but not anymore.  Not for PyCharm.  Don't know Komodo.
Does wingide have better support for other languages now?
@gthank Awesome ... the fact that plugin exists makes me want to try it even more ...
ooh I like that source assistant thingy in wingware
I normally use vim, but there are nice things about pycharm and the others
Pretty sure the answer is no for Komodo too
@ericasberry If you give it a go, try the vi emulation plugin. It's solid, though I constantly miss my vim plugins and .vimrc tweaks.
@ericasberry I'm a macvim fan and heavy user. Sadly I can't expect noob co-workers to figure it out and learn to code at the same time. If it was my shop it'd be a requirement
I currently alternate between vim and Eclipse with PyDev (I'm a Java refuge)
I use vwrapper in Eclipse but it's buggy
@ericasberry I think there's vi emulation in PyCharm and Komodo
@smithkevinc That's good to know and nice to have
Also vi support in Wing.
YES A VIM BROTHER!
Anyone try the new features in Wing 4?
Cool.  Well for me its a draw between Wing and PyCharm... just have to try them.  Emacs is a non-starter for me :)
Visual Studio on Linux is sweet ;)
So if I develop on Windows and Linux do I have to buy two licenses for these products?
No
As of Wing 4 license scheme changed. I believe it's no longer that way.

PyCharm is free for educators/schools which was obviously a big plus for me. Wing just offers a discounted license. Unfortunately, PyCharm isn't the best editor for 8 year old systems with 256 megs of RAM. That probably holds true for Komodo and Wing as well.
A most excellent and manly IDE smackdown
Biggest complaint I have about PyCharm is that when starting w/ a new virtualenv or something like that, it will take over your system parsing the stuff initially.  My lappy hates that.
@JoeTennies That's probably it's IDEA roots. It's initial indexing of my Java projects is… resource-intensive.
@JoeTennies I have tried WingIDE 4, the new feature Matplotlib support, and refactoring is impressive.
Scribes is not an IDE, but is a very neat editor for Linux :) http://scribes.sourceforge.net/
@jrt369 I don't think WingIDE works well on a 256M RAM old pc. WingIDE is free for open source develop. and it lools Pycharm need more computer performance than WingIDE
WingIDE has similar thing for Open Source developers. http://wingware.com/store/free
This is of course for PyCharm.
Addendum: hmmm, I joked earlier in the thread about PyCharm discount, but found there's a card in the swag bag with a code for a 50% off PyCon '11 special for Wingware Pro through 3/28.   :)
If you can show yourself as part of active Open Source project with community of contributors, they have a deal where can get free licence. http://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/buy/buy.jsp#opensource_
Not sure if mod_wsgi fails the condition 'you have a dedicated website and an active developer community supporting your project'. Does a one man project qualify. ;-)

I was wavering on PyCharm, but 1.2 was just released with academic pricing ($30 if you are a student!) http://blogs.jetbrains.com/pycharm/2011/03/pycharm-1-2-released-with-a-new-academic-license-type/

@ericasberry re PyCharm discount... do you mind sharing it (i think it's the same for all, ie not unique)?... :) I got the bag at PyCon too, and since I was planning to get PyCharm anyway I thought it's a really nice thing... but misplaced the card somewhere, what's left now is the PyCharm cheatsheet... :(
@rytis I had joked about a PyCharm discount; but the Pycon discount I found in the bag is for wingware professional.  The code is pyc2011
@ericasberry ah ok :) well that'd be why i couldn't find it then! i still have wingware code though, but thanks! :)
PyCharm was heavily discounted for Beta users, I seem to remember (though I didn't go for it)
I can't get WING IDE's menu to work with Ubuntu Natty's unified menu thing.
Is that because WingIDE is a PyQt-based app, do you think?
@holdenweb  WingIDE is a PyGTK-based APP

I'm a bit unclear about the unified menu's requirements but try running Wing with --system-gtk option to see if it works any better.  We ship with a fairly old GTK, although I'm not certain using the system GTK will help as it may be we need to change our code for the menu stuff to work.
@sdeibel Thanks for your feedback but I'm afraid that din't help
@lvh OK, thanks for letting me know.
